sec.title: Foreword
sec.p: ISO (the International Organization for Standardization) and IEC (the International Electrotechnical Commission) form the specialized system for worldwide standardization. National bodies that are members of ISO or IEC participate in the development of International Standards through technical committees established by the respective organization to deal with particular fields of technical activity. ISO and IEC technical committees collaborate in fields of mutual interest. Other international organizations, governmental and non-governmental, in liaison with ISO and IEC, also take part in the work.

The procedures used to develop this document and those intended for its further maintenance are described in the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 1. In particular, the different approval criteria needed for the different types of document should be noted. This document was drafted in accordance with the editorial rules of the ISO/IEC Directives, Part 2 (see www.iso.org/directives)

Attention is drawn to the possibility that some of the elements of this document may be the subject of patent rights. ISO and IEC shall not be held responsible for identifying any or all such patent rights. Details of any patent rights identified during the development of the document will be in the Introduction and/or on the ISO list of patent declarations received (see www.iso.org/patents) or the IEC list of patent declarations received (see https://patents.iec.ch).
Any trade name used in this document is information given for the convenience of users and does not constitute an endorsement.

For an explanation of the voluntary nature of standards, the meaning of ISO specific terms and expressions related to conformity assessment, as well as information about ISO’s adherence to the World Trade Organization (WTO) principles in the Technical Barriers to Trade (TBT) see www.iso.org/iso/foreword.html. In the IEC, see www.iec.ch/understanding-standards.
This document was prepared by ISO/IEC JSEG 15, Metaverse.

Any feedback or questions on this document should be directed to the user’s national standards body. A complete listing of these bodies can be found at www.iso.org/members.html and www.iec.ch/national-committees.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This document presents terms and definitions for concepts relevant to the Metaverse.
Specifically, the terminology presented in this document:

list-item.p: serve as a sound basis in the understanding of Metaverse;
guide new developments in the field by underpinning mutual understanding; and
serve as a quick and handy reference for those newly introduced to this field.

sec.title: Scope
sec.p: This document provides a concept system and a standard set of terminology related to the Metaverse, from basic concepts to those of the Metaverse ecosystem.
The scope of the vocabulary provided in this document corresponds to that of ISO/IEC JSEG 15.

sec.title: Normative references
sec.p: There are no normative references in this document.

sec.title: Terms and definitions
sec.p: For the purposes of this document, the following terms and definitions apply.
ISO and IEC maintain terminology databases for use in standardization at the following addresses:

list-item.p: ISO Online browsing platform: available at https://www.iso.org/obp

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: virtual world (3.1.18) experienced through immersive (3.1.14) technologies
capacity of computers or other machines to exhibit or simulate intelligent behavior
piece of equipment, product system, hardware, software or service that is used to enable, maintain or improve functional capabilities of individuals with disabilities
paradigm for enabling network access to a scalable and elastic pool of shareable physical or virtual resources with self-service provisioning and administration on-demand
identifier in the format of the W3C Decentralized Identifier
realistic virtual human representations created using advanced simulation technology
digital representation of an object of interest
tbx:langSet.tbx:note: A digital twin may require different capabilities (e.g., synchronization, real-time support) according to the specific domain of application.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: model of computing in which a set of nodes coordinates its activities by means of digital messages passed between the nodes
a ledger (3.1.17) that is shared across a set of DLT nodes and synchronized between the DLT nodes using a consensus mechanism
asset that exists only in digital form or which is the digital representation of another asset
information used by information systems to represent an external agent, a person, organization, application, or device
distributed computing (3.1.8) in which processing and storage takes place at or near the edge, where the nearness is defined by the system’s requirements
device that provides an entry point into enterprise or service provider core networks
tbx:langSet.tbx:example: Gateways, routers, switches, multiplexers, and a variety of other access devices.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: creating the illusion of being inside a computer-generated scene

system of entities (including cyber-physical devices, information resources, and people) that exchange information and interact with the physical world by sensing, processing information, and actuating
ability of two or more systems or applications to exchange information and to mutually use the information that has been exchanged
information store that keeps records of transactions that are intended to be final, definitive and immutable
simulated environment that can be accessed by multiple users through an online interface
tbx:langSet.tbx:note: The simulated environments are often interactive.
The physical world in which people live, and the related characteristics, will be referred to as the “real world” to differentiate it from a virtual world.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: 3-D virtual scene replicating office space of an organization, providing users with an immersive (3.1.14) experience
content created by users within the metaverse (3.1.1)
tbx:langSet.tbx:note: UGC is often facilitated by simplified editing tools.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: metaverse (3.1.1) that integrates virtual and physical realities to create a sophisticated digital industrial ecosystem, enhancing real-world processes through virtual simulations and strengthening the entire industrial and value chain with increased intelligence, collaboration, openness, service orientation, and interconnectivity
metaverse (3.1.1) enabling a new type of financial business where the physical world and the mirrored digital world are symbiotic
metaverse (3.1.1) enabling a multi-sensory immersive (3.1.14) classroom connecting virtual and reality, enabling knowledge acquisition, participation, and creation
metaverse (3.1.1) that enables the digital, intelligent and accurate medical information platform that breaks space-time restrictions and technical barriers of the original medical system
metaverse (3.1.1) that enables marketing towards users, creating personalized, emotional and social marketing scenes through metaverse technology and content
metaverse (3.1.1) that enables the evolution of gaming that embodies four characteristics: immersion, accessibility, accessibility and extensibility
metaverse (3.1.1) that creates a holographic virtual reality that integrates the advantages of online and offline social networking, using AR (3.3.2), VR (3.3.4), XR (3.3.1) and other technologies
environments experienced through human-machine sensory interactions commonly composed of real world and virtual elements
tbx:langSet.tbx:note: Extended reality covers virtual reality (3.3.4), augmented reality (3.3.2) and mixed reality (3.3.3) environments.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: interactive experience of a real-world environment whereby the objects that reside in the real world are augmented by computer-generated perceptual information
display continuum in which both real and virtual images are combined in some way and in some proportion
tbx:langSet.tbx:note: Augmented reality and virtual reality are considered to be on the mixed reality continuum.
tbx:langSet.tbx:source: ISO/IEC TR 23843:2020, 3.4, modified — added Note 1 to entry.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: artificial environment presented in the computer
system that uses a mixture of representations of physical world data and virtual world data as its presentation medium
integration of real and virtual worlds including mixed reality (3.3.3) and augmented reality (3.3.2)
tbx:langSet.tbx:note: MAR is often used interchangeably with MR.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: low-carbon social metaverse under the Web 3.0 architecture, aiming to build a new green and energy-saving digital economy
role, position, individual, organization, or classes thereof, having an interest, right, share, or claim, in an entity of interest
tbx:langSet.tbx:example: End users, operators, acquirers, owners, suppliers, architects, developers, builders, maintainers, regulators, taxpayers, certifying agencies, and markets.

tbx:langSet.tbx:definition: way of thinking about an entity of interest, especially as it relates to concerns
tbx:langSet.tbx:source: ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2022, 3.18, modified — The original example has been removed.

sec.title: General
sec.p: The definition of a “metaverse” has long been subject of controversy.

sec.title: Approach
sec.p: In order to define any concept, it is necessary to determine the essential characteristics of the concept, where additions or subtractions to these characteristics will no longer define the concept.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The word “metaverse” originated from the science fiction Snow Crash written by Neal Stephenson in 1992 [23] .

In popular culture, the term “metaverse” is commonly used as a generalized entity beyond the Internet, as a massively multi-player virtual world experienced through immersive technologies with comprehensive sensory integration through human computer interfaces.
The group has considered a few popular definitions of the “metaverse”, including:

list-item.p: From [20] : “universal, immersive virtual world that is facilitated by virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR)”
From [21] : persistent and immersive simulated world that is experienced in the first person by large groups of simultaneous users who share a strong sense of mutual presence
From [22] : an infinite and persistent set of computer-generated virtual worlds that may be accessed via some human computer interface

sec.title: Considerations
sec.p: WS 1 has considered various definitions, common perspectives and expectations on the term “metaverse” and has come to the following conclusions based on consensus.
Essential characteristics of the “metaverse” include:

list-item.p: virtual, as in the items in the experience is virtual
immersive where it is experienced through human computer interaction

sec.p: Common characteristics expected by popular culture include:

list-item.p: massively multi-user where there can be many simultaneous users
interoperability between users across virtual world systems
persistent where actions and events in the virtual world persists after a user leaves
real-time where user actions are performed in real-time

sec.p: The resulting consensus arrived at this definition for “metaverse”:

disp-quote.p: metaverse: virtual world experienced through immersive technologies

def.p: collective reference to both AR and VR
